text: Hey <@U639Y9AQJ> - what's your goals for this year? What's your expectations and desired results by the end of it?
Ah I see. Was it like a team-building day not related to work.

Goals for thus year is to be happy in my workplace. I'm currently at a dead end factory job, which I hate, but have been offered an accounting apprenticeship starting later this year. Just deciding  whether it's the right career for me.
Great news. Always feel positive about change.
The team-building day included both work related and non-work related tasks.
Reason being is that through your core skills people can evaluate your workplace persona, what can you offer, how do we fit in our roles and where can they come in and help you.
And then through your non-core skills and understand your personality, ambitions, fears, mentality and how all these do fit your current career plans alongside the team.
Having said that, I can definitely help with your direction. Currently in that path myself.
Okay, so a long post about my life story. Sort of.

Ive always been strong with maths and its generally a favourite subject of mine. I've always been "good-close to-great" at it. eg in GCSE, i was 2 marks off an A*. At A-level, i Was 5 marks off a B (If i had got this, i feel my life would have changed completely as i would have been available for more positions. instead, I got 3 C's in computing and physics). Anyways, After college, i knew university wasn't for me so i looked for apprenticeships. After many interviews for a whole range or roles, i Ultimately took a reality check and did an IT apprenticeship at a local school earning apprentice minimum wage. Whilst here, I got an idea that maybe IT wasnt for me, atleast this side of it as i was more into coding.  More importanly though, i got experience, which is what stopped me from getting the job in previous interviews. or so they say, but in reality, it was just an easier way of saying we dont want you.

This lasted 18 months and soon after, I got a job at my friends parents factory on what was supposed to be for the christmas period (3 months). Nearly 2 years later and i'm still here but with a somewhat clear idea that the financial world is what i want to go in. I was very interested in Actuarial but to start that apprenticeship, you needed a B in maths, minimum :upside_down_face: So that left me with accounting. Now my father was an accountant for the council years ago, and he got to it through luck and hard work and so he's made a good career out of himself. Times have changed now, meaning its a lot harder, but I still feel its a good profession to get into.

The course i'll be joining ion september is with the civil service and it teaches AAT upto level 4 over 3 years. It will require me to move away from home, to the other side of the country in fact. And living independently is not something I've ever done. Especially since I dont know anyone there. Now, if this was closer to home, id be over the moon with the job, especially since i've been rejected countless amount of times, but now i'm having doubts. Like, is AAT something I really want to do? is accounting in general something i could see myself doing? How hard is it for someone of my level? I probably wont have much social life to being with so i guess its not worth worrying how the exams+work will affect my balance to begin with.

I did go for an interview this past Friday. Again, it would have required me to move but I would have been more confident in doing so to this location. And the course was for CIMA over 18 months. So it was a great course + short duration meaning had I not enjoyed living there, i wont have been stuck for long. And today, i got the outcome which was, you guessed it, failed. Again. I'm really interested in Cima more as its supposed to be easier + theres good career prospects. But applying for somethign like this, it means I can target a specific qualification and complete it fully within 4/5 years as opposed to doing AAT over 3 years then spending another 3 (?) years achieving CIMA. But is it actually any good? Is it better to go through the AAT route? Sorry for the long post, and thanks for reading it all (If you do :slightly_smiling_face: )
